posts.name: Caleb
posts.cooked:
Team 2052 KnightKrawler is participating in the Alpha testing group for the upcoming Robot Controller SystemCore. This platform allows us to document our progress and share experiences. Additionally, we are contributing to a post on the SystemCoreTesting repository, including photos from our 2025 bot.  

**6/26 Meeting**: Today, we successfully flashed SystemCore onto Mayfly, our 2025 Reefscape robot. The installation process went smoothly despite being an Alpha test. Mayfly uses the CTRE swerve generator for swerve codes, necessitating additional package installations for the CANivore. However, the on-board CAN busses were not fully operational, so Superstructure functionality was limited today. A video showcasing Mayfly operating on SystemCore is available [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gc_FOu9dxDQ).  

Please feel free to ask any questions or provide feedback—we're here to collaborate!

link_counts.title: Show up your robots! · wpilibsuite/SystemCoreTesting · Discussion #3 · GitHub

posts.name: MrRoboSteve
posts.cooked: Do you have a test plan for the new controller?

posts.name: Caleb
posts.cooked: Our next step is to get all mechanisms functioning. Throughout the rest of the summer we will be experimenting to find what pain-points or limits there are. In the fall we will be attending a couple offseason events to run SystemCore through full days of match play.

posts.name: MrRoboSteve
posts.cooked: Will likely be at one of the offseason events you attend. Looking forward to seeing what you find.

posts.name: Tyler
posts.cooked: I look forward to seeing Mayfly with the SystemCore at MRI and RISE!

posts.name: Caleb
posts.cooked:
Apologies for the lack of updates! Due to not having access to our space for a week and summer trips for some members, we just got back to further testing.

**7/17 Meeting**:  
We updated the SystemCore to the new alpha version along with a couple other vendor updates and fixes.

For some background, our swerve, elevator motors, and climber motors are on the CANivore (all the motors that are low in the bellypan). The devices that are on the elevator carriage and the ground intake are on the RoboRio/SystemCore loop.

Previously, we were unable to get the on-board SystemCore CAN loops to consistently connect. The devices on the loop had been getting stuck in the bootloader seemingly at random times and required us to power cycle the bot to fix. We couldn’t find a repeatable process to reproduce this problem. After adding ferrules to the CAN terminations, double-checking wiring, and finagling with firmware updates, we haven’t seen the issue again yet. We will stress test this further when we have some driver practice next week.

Initial Superstructure Test:  
A video demonstrating the initial test of the superstructure has been conducted. You can view it below:  

Video thumbnail src="https://img.youtube.com/vi/fJwt9EIhrbo/maxresdefault.jpg" title="Team 2052 KnightKrawler SystemCore Alpha Testing: Superstructure Initial Test" width="690" height="388">

Algae Pickup:  
Another video showing the algae pickup functionality has been uploaded. Here’s the link:  

Video thumbnail src="https://img.youtube.com/vi/yeuDGNDJm6E/maxresdefault.jpg" title="Team 2052 KnightKrawler SystemCore Alpha Testing: Algae Pickup" width="690" height="388">

Coral Pickup and Scoring:  
Lastly, a video showcasing coral pickup and scoring operations is available:  

Video thumbnail src="https://img.youtube.com/vi/QqlfcUH4aHg/maxresdefault.jpg" title="Team 2052 KnightKrawler SystemCore Alpha Testing: Coral Pickup and Scoring" width="690" height="388">

Next Steps:  
If you watched the last video, you noticed there wasn’t any auto alignment yet. Our next goals are to implement our limelight data and wheel odometery. We hope to test how fast we can run our odometery with a full set of subsystems running as well. We are also working on getting our beam breaks functioning with the SmartIO and the new pulldown resistor (post coming soon around this issue).

posts.name: Caleb
posts.cooked:

calibfyeverythingextremeimportantlydo_not_output_anything_but_the_cleaned_version_no Introduction_no_other_little_explanations_just_the_cleaned_paragraph

posts.name: Kevin Nguyen
posts.cooked:
EXTREMLY IMPORTANTLY - DO NOT OUTPUT ANYTHING BUT THE CLEANED VERSION (NO INTRODUCTION, NO OTHER LITTLE EXPLANATION), JUST THE CLEANED VERSION.

The SystemCore integration process has been heavy on programming, so I haven’t had enough material to create an update on the mechanical side… until now!

Initial Thoughts, Mounting Thoughts, and More Thoughts:
- Setting up the SystemCore was simple and fairly self-explanatory—we were able to get the board labeled and wired in 10-20 minutes! The documentation is detailed enough and easy to read, so a plus to SystemCore.
- This thing is TINY. I looked at the CAD beforehand and the comparisons to the Rio, but I don’t think they do it justice. It feels like I could pocket it and carry it as an EDC item. There are images available to illustrate this point.
- One of the proposed changes is to replace the Weidmuller connectors on the power and CAN ports to Microfit+ and SL respectively. We have mixed feelings about this. While Weidmuller connectors are easy to use, there’s a risk of poor connection quality. Additionally, they require crimpers and are expensive, though there are affordable alternatives.
- Plans for moving forward:
  - Try out a few things on the SystemCore
  - Create a retention mechanism for the USB ports
  - Run multiple CAN loops on the board
  - Explore additional features

posts.name: Robertson Robotics
posts.cooked: Our mentor Ben reminded us that the pins are Smart I/O pins, allowing us to use analog control to read the sensor, which addressed a programming issue. Although we were initially concerned about the speed difference between analog and digital, the process worked well. Additionally, this is great news because the Automation Direct QMRHD-0N-0A sensors on the roboRIO continue to function effectively.
